node.title: 'This is a new era for us': Tasmanian healthcare workers prepare to live and work with COVID
node.alt: A building facade behind tree branches
node.description: Tasmania is preparing to manage inevitable COVID cases when borders open next week — but healthcare workers are concerned about the resilience of a system already under strain.
node.content:
["There have been warnings for years that Tasmania's health system is at a crisis point and the COVID-19 pandemic brought that into sharp relief.\u00a0", "Hospital emergency departments have been places of acute pressure, where the impacts of bed shortages are most keenly felt.", "But with Tasmania's borders reopening on December 15, there is trepidation among hospital staff about how an already stretched health system will cope.\u00a0", "\"There is a level of anxiety among my colleagues because we know that COVID is at the front door,\" said Tom Millen, an Australian Nursing and Midwifery Federation (ANMF) representative in the Launceston General Hospital's emergency department.\u00a0", "Tasmanian secretary of health Kathrine Morgan-Wicks said there would be changes to how hospitals operated to reduce the risk of transmission, with every person presenting at an emergency department treated as potentially infectious.", "\"You will see some changes in our hospital environment, which may include triage external to the emergency department in open conditions while we do a rapid antigen test, for example,\u00a0if you are presenting with respiratory symptoms,\" she said.\u00a0", "", "
Patients will see changes to hospital emergency department admissions processes to prevent COVID transmission.(ABC News: Luke Bowden)
", "Dr Juan Ascensio-Lane, the Tasmanian chair of the Australasian College for Emergency Medicine, warned Tasmanians to be prepared for changes, regardless of how well-prepared the health system is.\u00a0", "\"On a day-to-day basis things will change, it's hard to predict, we can look to Victoria and New South Wales for the lessons learnt there,\" he said.", "
Retention concerns remain despite increased recruitment
", "There have been additional resources poured into the system for the expected surge in demand once COVID-19 is circulating in the community, including an additional 152 beds and 840 full-time-equivalent staff.\u00a0", "Ms Morgan-Wicks said these measures were\u00a0already easing pressure on the state's emergency departments.\u00a0", "\"Over the last four weeks we've actually had quite lower escalation, particularly at our Royal Hobart emergency department,\" Ms Morgan-Wicks said.\u00a0", "", "
Kathrine Morgan-Wicks is confident Tasmania's healthcare system is ready to manage COVID cases.(ABC News: Loretta Lohberger)
", "Despite the additional recruitment, Mr Millen said it was\u00a0not enough to offset the numbers of skilled, experienced staff leaving nursing or reducing their hours in the past 12 months.\u00a0", "\"You can't train up new staff quickly, the government's been doing pretty well on recruitment but it's failed miserably on retention and we are losing skilled staff so rapidly, it's like a revolving door,\" he said.\u00a0", "", "
Tom Millen is concerned about the impact positive COVID cases will have on the state's healthcare workforce.(ABC News: Piia Wirsu)
", "
'It's something that's really scary'
", "Staff are concerned there has not been enough consideration given to workforce planning \u2014 including how the workforce will be filled when health staff have to isolate if they contract the virus.", "Staffing was a major challenge in the 2020 north-west COVID outbreak, which saw the closure of the North West Regional and North West Private hospitals.", "During the shutdown, 1,300 staff were put into quarantine for two weeks to stamp out the virus.\u00a0", "This time around, vaccinations are available and have been made mandatory for all health workers to reduce potential transmission of the virus\u00a0and severe symptoms.\u00a0", "The isolation period for the fully vaccinated health workforce is 10 days, instead of the\u00a0previous 14 days \u2014 the same time period for the general population who are unvaccinated against COVID.", "If health workers become close contacts as a result of exposure in a healthcare setting, or there is a breach of personal protective equipment, that will be examined at the time.\u00a0", "Ms Morgan-Wicks said public health authorities were\u00a0relying on having a fully vaccinated health workforce and taking a precautionary approach to using PPE to ensure large numbers of staff were not\u00a0taken out of the system.\u00a0", "\"For high-risk areas, it will be the use of N95 masks and goggles, which then means under the furloughing policy that it is a low-risk treatment and they are able to continue to work in most cases,\" she said.\u00a0", "", "
Tasmania has stockpiled large amounts of PPE in preparation for reopening its borders.(ABC News: Patrick Stone)
", "But Mr Millen fears the ongoing issues around workforce planning will prove problematic.\u00a0", "\"What we haven't had communicated to us frontline workers is a strategy about how the workforce is going to be maintained,\" Mr Millen said.\u00a0", "\"How are we going to staff our emergency departments, our ICUs, our wards, our medi-hotels, COVID in the home?", "
Preparations to protect cancer patients
", "Other challenges also emerged from the north-west outbreak, including a reduction in cancer screenings and diagnoses \u2014\u00a0something that has been echoed internationally and interstate.\u00a0", "\"There is a large trial from the US, presented earlier this year, that shows for breast [cancer], for cervical cancer, for colorectal cancer, screening has decreased by some 40 per cent compared to pre-COVID,\" oncologist Dr Stan Gauden said.\u00a0", "\"The same holds to a lesser extent, but more or less the same numbers [were found] in Victoria after their extended lockdown.\"", "", "
Dr Gauden is concerned he will see a decline in cancer screening rates once COVID arrives in Tasmania.(ABC News: Piia Wirsu)
", "Dr Gauden said cancer patients were also more at risk from potential infection.\u00a0", "\"Cancer patients that develop a COVID infection have first of all a higher risk of getting that infection, a higher risk of developing a more severe illness, complications, and indeed death than the normal population,\" he said.\u00a0", "Provision of cancer services has moved online as much as possible to reduce infection risk to patients.\u00a0", "Ms Morgan-Wicks hopes the preparation of systems and additional resources will ensure normal health services can continue uninterrupted.\u00a0", "\"High levels of vaccinations and COVID@home will help to ease pressure on our hospitals and allow them to keep operating normally for as long as possible,\" she said.\u00a0", "", "
